Photo and caption by David Moynahan The "success" of this test shot was an accident. I was shooting through a glass-bottomed bucket with an off camera flash in a dry bag held underwater near the scallop. The intention was for the sea grass a couple feet below to make a soft natural background, but I had the aperture stopped too far down so the background came out nearly black. The silt that I had inadvertently stirred up was picked up by the flash, creating the "stars" in this cosmos, and completing the alien-in-outer-space image. -- Share your own photos on National Geographic's Your Shot, or rate your favorites, and the photo could appear on the National Geographic website, in the National Geographic Magazine or in future galleries here on Facebook. Their "formation", in a V, was a sight I hadn't seen before. I only had a minute or two to get this shot as they were heading towards our location (we were between them and the water hole). I got out of our vehicle, faced them straight on, shot a few frames, and then got back in the car. I hiked to where it dropped out of the sight and found it sitting on an unusual roost--a young Galapagos tortoise. Photo and caption by Nate Zeman I dug a small pit, big enough for my camera to fit in, just inches from this ghost crab's hole. With my lens at beach level, I hooked up my shutter cable release and hoped to catch the crab as it emerged from its hole. My lens choice and framing were all very intentional. I wanted to capture a dramatic scene with the small crab appearing much larger in the foreground, hopefully conveying what the world might look like from the level of a tiny ghost crab. Taken on the island of Tortola. -- Share your own photos on National Geographic's Your Shot, or rate your favorites, and the photo could appear on the National Geographic website, in the National Geographic Magazine or in future galleries here on Facebook. Photo and caption by Brad Goldpaint Double Arch, in southern Utah, was formed differently than most arches in the Arches National Park. It is what is known as a pothole arch, formed by water erosion from above rather than more typical erosion from the side. The larger opening has a span of 148 feet and a height of 104 feet. It lies atop an underground salt bed called the Paradox Formation, which is responsible for the arches. The visible rock formation is the salmon-colored entrada sandstone and the tan-colored Navajo sand. -- Share your own photos on National Geographic's Your Shot, or rate your favorites, and the photo could appear on the National Geographic website, in the National Geographic Magazine or in future galleries here on Facebook. Photo and caption by T. Jeffery Clarke Trajan's Kiosk, an hypaethryal (roofless) temple, originally stood on the island of Philae, where it came to have the nickname 'Pharaoh's Bed.' One of the largest of ancient Egyptian monuments, with 14 massive columns, it was moved to Agilika Island in the Nile in the 1960s by UNESCO to avoid the rising floodwaters after the construction of the Aswan Dam. Reliefs inside the temple walls depict the emperor Trajan (as a pharaoh) offering sacrifices to Osiris, Isis and Horus. -- Share your own photos on National Geographic's Your Shot, or rate your favorites, and the photo could appear on the National Geographic website, in the National Geographic Magazine or in future galleries here on Facebook. Photo and caption by Danish Khan My first attempt at star trails had to be at the backdrop of the world's ninth highest peak, Nanga Parbat in Pakistan's Gilgit-Baltistan region up north. This is its Raikot face, from where it has been scaled only twice. The first ever successful ascent by Hermann Buhl in 1953 was also from this side of the mountain. One can also see the Milky Way trailing from the left. I placed my tripod at the enchanting Fairy Meadows and let the shutter loose for 30 minutes, just before the moon rise. -- Share your own photos on National Geographic's Your Shot, or rate your favorites, and the photo could appear on the National Geographic website, in the National Geographic Magazine or in future galleries here on Facebook. Friday Fact: A flamingo can eat only when its head is upside down.

10153513995733951-comments:
Frans Ettiene Terblanche2 days agoHERE IT IS!!!!! GOOGLE is awesome. .. Flamingos feed with their heads down, and their bills are adapted accordingly. In most birds a smaller lower beak works against a larger upper one. In flamingos this is reversed; the lower bill is much larger and stronger, and the fat tongue runs within the bill's deep central groove. To complete the jaw reversal, unlike other birds (and mammals) the upper jaw is not rigidly fixed to the skull. Consequently, with the bird's head upside down during feeding the upper bill moves up and down, permitting the flamingo's jaws to work "normally."

Siobain Mulcahy4 months agoTake the time to read what was written with the pix submission!Karine Aigner Humans differ from chimpanzees in only 1.2% of our DNA. We are similar in appearances, emotions, actions and self-awareness, yet we treat our closest cousins as beasts. Tarzan the chimp was raised in captivity for a life as a performer. But, like many other exotic pets, when he became too large and dangerous to live in his owner’s home, he was moved to the Black Pine Animal Sanctuary in Indiana. Here, he could live for another 50 years. Primates are highly social creatures, yet Tarzan lives alone in his huge enclosure. His only contact is with his compassionate caregivers and visitors to the sanctuary. Primates require significant mental stimulation; Tarzan watches the humans that come to watch him. At first the chimpanzee’s steely gaze intimidated these young boys. Then, gaining confidence, they began to pull faces and make “ooh ooh ooh” noises. “Tarzan looked at them impassively. Then he seemed to look through and beyond them as if to another life. At that moment, my heart broke,” says Karine. “Today, so many young people are disconnected from nature. It’s not surprising they have no empathy with a captive animal. But by teaching them to love, value and respect nature, perhaps we can empower them to fight for it – and make sure that, on their watch, animals that belong in the wild, stay in the wild.”

Friday Fact: Saturn, being made mostly of gas, is the only planet that could float in water.

Open In Facebook
10152851498213951-comments:
Wes Hartley11 months agoIf it had an impermeable membrane to contain its component gases, maybe. But assuming there was enough water to do this, the gravity of such an ocean would simply destroy Saturn. It would then either be absorbed as bubbles or remain on top as an atmosphere. The core itself would likely sink.

Bird Phlava11 months agoEarth will too...can't see why this would even be an argument. the question here would be what's "enough water"?

Michael Mendoza11 months agoNo, it would not float. The dense core would sink like a rock and the gas wouldn't even dip below the water. The planet would disintegrate, it WOULD NOT float.

Tony LiVigni11 months agoI don't know that it would still be a gas planet identifiable as Saturn, that would now be floating on water. Wouldn't any body of water coming close enough to Saturn quickly combine with it as it was approaching? Due to gravity, they would pull together, resulting in a planet with a water core and Saturn's gases as the new atmosphere. You couldn't have an un-contained gas sphere floating above a body of water, and not spread out into an even layer over it. But, is it possible that if Saturn completely froze and the water remained liquid it could work? Maybe there is an astrophysicist here to answer that? Neil DeGrasse Tyson, you out there? We need a batman style spotlight for you.
